titleStmt.title: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p. Paginated [1]-19, wanting p. 5, 14 (two p. 15).

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Anon.
"For many centuries after Britain became an island" the hist

orian says " "the untamed forest was king." Its
mosit moist and
mssy mossy floor was hidden from heavens eye by a close drawn
curtain of innumerable treetops. " On the matted bough

innumerable birds
snag sang ; but their song was only heard by a

few skin clad hunters in the
claetings clearings . Did the desire

to sing come to one of those huntsmen savages because he
geard heard the
birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a
moment? Anyhow, the tree was felled; some sort of hut
was made from its branches; and the clearing became larger;

the birds
f er fewer ; and the human voice sang instead. The first
songs are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs;
winter songs.

quote.l: The lutel foul hath hire wyl
By a bank as I lay
And me thought in her lay
She said winter was past, hey ho!

p.l: They were out of door songs, because there was no
comfort indoors, little light, and no books. The eye
therefore was more active in in ourselves. The eye is the
young sense; the sense that is attached to the body.

Now and then, by
chooisng choosing a view carefully to shut out
a chimney or a bungalow, we can still see a fragment of
of what they saw-- a flat fen, reed whispering, water
logged; or a down still covered with turf only.
On the down is the green scar still, to mark the
road along which the travellers came, past the circle where
they were buried; past the stone that marks the meeting place
or the burial place.
but if Anon sings because love and spring make him
vocal or the horror of winter dark But, who listens? Somebody
heard that particular song, or it would not have been written

down. The singer then had his
audeince audience ; but the audience was
so little interested in his name that he never thought to
give it.
It was the printed book with the authors name attached that
was the death of Anon. After thatThe audience was separated from
the singer. After that ( 1478) the sing was attached to
the singer. Anon gives place to James or Thomas; he lives in
in a house; and he has books.
The heart of this vast proliferation of printed
pages is the song. The song has the same power over the
reader in the 2o 20 th century as over the hearer in the

11th. To enjoy singing, to enjoy
h aring hearing the song,
must be the deepest rooted and tough of human instincts.
It is an instinct of self-preservation, for only when we
put two and two together to we overcome dissolution. Two

lines, two words, two
bri cks bricks make way against oblivion.
Making whatever it is gives us life; and the passion
with which we seek for these creations, and attempt to
make them, is of a piece with the instinct that
sets us preserving our bodies from wet, or cold.
But with the printing press came into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books
themselves and the readers of books. Could we at this
this moment X ray the singers mind we shound find

a nimbus surrounding the song; a
st eam stream of

influences to which so many ugly
abstarct abstract names have been
given-- influences of society; of education; of

class; material; economic of
econmic economic stress. So many are they and so
obscure that we may call them nonsense names--
say Nin, Crot and Pully. Nin Crot and Pully are always

at their task.
?ore More and more [complex]

at their work--tugging, obscuring, distracting.
invisble invisible some only visible to the writer; others only visible in [rear?]
to the sufferer himself often. More and more complex
they become as time passes. The song is only to be discovered
in the instantaneous way in which instaneously; in a flash
of recognition; some say they feel it when their beards
brsitle bristle ; others that a thrill runs down the nerves of the
thigh. But the song is there still...
Waves...

That babbling child-like-
stroy story teller, thatthe gossip at

the farm door, that innocent eyed, very naked,
u tful lustful ,

religious singer, that great a[illeg.] & new & aged great artist, Anon, died
thn then

in in 1476&. With
hi him died something in the audience-- the

They
nollonger no longer their filled in the
payses pauses , and joined in the chorus

To
follw follow his
firtunes fortunes
futhrer further , we must turn to an outsider.
one of those commentators who tell us so much about the
invisib invisible influences; about Nin, Crot and Pulley.. His name was
Anon had sung his song at the back door in a jargon that was
as uncouth and far [illeg.] barbarous to Harrison
as to ourselves; and more barbarous

quote.l: Ichot from heven it is me sent

p.l: the words were as difficult for him to spell out as for us;

and more for him painful; they were [such?] reminders of a savagery of low
b rth birth
of indignity tokens of base birth, of a close savage past.

In the background, making a of
Har isons Harrison's mind stood
the Greeks and the romans; Henrcus Cornelius Agrippa;

Suetonius; Pliny, Cicero. Those were the
anicenits ancients who

occupied the same place in Harrisons mind that the
Elizabetha Elizabethans
occupy in our minds. The readers of his time read the
classics, Those were the valuable books that

were chained to the
sleves shelves in college libraries. The
leanred learned
read them; and the nobles too. "...our ancient ladies of the

court" were to be found reading the holy
scrpitures scriptures as

they did their
needlwork needlework ; and histories;

The great Elizabethan house is still in
exist nce existence ,
sxpxmx standing in its green island of [herb?] grass, separated
often from the high road only by a sunk dip in the
ground and a low red an old wall. It can be seen lying there, out of
proprtion proportion somehow, Either it is too big, or the village

with its
eignteen eighteenth
ce tury century and
tw ntieth twentieth century shops and

villas is too small.
ith With its
congomeration conglomeration of roofs

and chimneys, garden and chapels, it dwarfs its
n ghbours neighbours .

the great
Elizabethna Elizabethan house
dwrafs dwarfs its
neig bours
Inside all is kept as if the Queen were expected. today

The rooms are
sti ll still the rooms the lords and
l ies ladies

lived in. The upright
Elizabethna Elizabethan chairs stand round the wall.
Their fringes and their tapestry is not much faded.
The great carved tables are polished nad lustrous.
The carved [great?] chests and cupboards look brand new.

Even the toys and
kicknacks knick-knacks have survived intact :/ inlaid

boxes; Here are the inlaid work boxes, and the that the Queen
nahdle [needled?]
as she sat upright on the faded pink day couch. And there,

is the swollen big
bel ied bellied lute or theorbo,
on which she played, still resonant. The floor
is strewn with rugs; the windows curtained with
silv r thraed silver thread brocades; and here are the cut glass Venice
chandeliers high from the [ceilings?] which lighted this byegone company.

But where are the Elizabethans people? They were more
ehmepral ephemeral

than their possessions. Human Life has
recded receded
fromthis from this
convoluted iridescent shell; with its fringes and its laces,

del.l:
its
elborate elaborate carved legs, its
lops loops and knots,
festoons and draperies upon which the spring sun of 1940

p.l: still shines so strong bright. There is a gulf between them and
ourselves. The chairs and tables are there; but the
Wilton Penshurst, Hardwick all are untenanted.
Only the furniture remains-- the lacquered, the

highly painted, the ornate, the
conv luted convoluted ; the chairs and
tables that must have been so so hard to sit upon;
If they were like their furniture, they were
at once ceremonious; and crude; fantastic yet sharp,
pointed, uncushioned;

The writer who hesitated conscious of his
pelebian plebian

bith birth on the threshold of the great roo, , he was still
unspeciali unspecialised
undifferentiated. His eye was stimulated; by the crimsons and

the golds and the greens of the
lothing clothing ; by the angles and

patterns on the
ceilinsg ceilings ; His ear too was stimulated and

peicked pricked by [words?]. Books were
rea read aloud; each word was given sharpness

and
subatnce substance by the speaking voice. And then when the lord

or lady took his lute and sang, lilt,
rhytm rhythm , melody was
addd added
to the substance and sharpness of the words. Words bubbled

in his mind, old words, English words,
rech French words,
Ladtin Latin

words. They were
motlen molten , capable of taking any shape, of

reflecting
nay coloure any colours , of
folliwng following the ones, of taking the

rhymn rhythm of the
l te lute . No grammar bound them tightly; nor did
one society inflict its canons of good taste.

Whether he
ws was to write or to sing or to paint was an open
uetion question . The arts were closely interwoven. For a moment

there is a pause on the threshold of the great
l zabethan Elizabethan

house, when the artist sees
begore before [here?] him three different paths.
Shall he sing, or paint, or make poems? And then there

rose up from the
couryard courtyard the crude [voices?] tones of the mummers.
It was the stagethat settled it. Had there been no stage,

no actors,
Shakeapere Shakespeare might
hev eben have been
Michael Angelo Michelangelo .

Spenser
a hael Raphael , and
Marloew Marlowe our first great musician.
The writer then came to birth with difficulty in England--
the writer who is distinct from the minstrel, whose words

are printed. For when familiar
lettees letters are written in
Biblical prose there must be a limit to his freedom
a barrier between what is sayable and what unsayable.
a limit thus to what he can put into words writing.
He is in being , at the beginning of the sixteenth century;

for the
priting printing press has given him a name; but he is still
unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist --the person

who stands
otside outside and [interjected?], by some impulse
desiring to observe to state rather than to take part -- is not wholly writer,
wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems possible
that the great English art may not be the art of words.

His eye like a painters, is alive to the
clour colour of
clothing, of country, of beats and birds; his ear, like
a musicians, is stimulated by the sound of words spoken aloud
His book What he wrote was read outaloud in company. "I spent most of my time"
wrote Lady Ann Clifford in playing Glocko at Glecko,

quote.l: and hearing Moll Neville read the Arcadia.".. Rivers used
to read to me on Montaigne and Moll Neville in the

p.l:
Faery Queen" (1617-1619) Every word had its
sharpnes sharpness weight
its weight & edge given to it by the speaking voice. And then the
lute and the virginals gave lilt, rhythm melody to the

written words. When the fire of London was burning and the citizens loading their goods
intob into boats

Pepys noted that "Hardly one lighter or
baot boat in three

l.quote: that had the goods of of a house in it, but there was a

p.l: pair of virginals in it." The writers mind was full

of
undiffrentiated undifferentiated words; old words, new words; French and
Latin. No grammar bound them tightly together. They were

elastic; they could be danced to and
su sung to. But in

psp te of nthat spite of that , they could not
follw follow the pace of the
private voice; the voice that talks intimately, briefly
easily colloquially in doors.
Spenser then--- a little man with short hair,
a small band, and cuffs--- standing on the threshold

of the great room at
Penshurt Penshurst was separate from Anon the sing

er singer ; and separate from
Holinsged Holinshed the
chornicler chronicler ; and
separate, in that he saw the scene with detachment from , the artists

point of view, from his audience. But the book which had
givn given
hisword his words aseparate existence, had brought into being a
little group of readers. And that public began at once at once to
exert its pressure. What is the book that will please
Sir Philip Sidney? What is the theme that will recommend

itself to the Queen? What must he
priase praise ? What must he reject
W at What will so work upon the audience that they will
procure for the poet a place, or a pension?
TheseFrom this time onward there are to be the always the

influences always tugging and
distrting distorting and
thwarting; as also they encourage, stimulate, draw out, help into
life the writers instinct. Some are visible only to the

writer himself; others only to the reader
i in time to come.
More and more complex they grow, as the book with the
authors name on it goes out into a more and more
more crowded numerous, a more divided audience, to a public which

[emerging from the
silce silence of the middle ages ] desires

according to its education, its poverty its to it
weath wealth , now history, now
instruction, now poetry itself, and now what will make them
forget the that life is ugly, or drab. As the book
becomes more covered over with these influences, the thing that the writer ser

set out to say becomes increasingly
encu bered encumbered . It is only

to be discovered in a flash of
recgnition recognition ; Some say they
feel it--the original, the vital--when their beards bristle.

Others that a
trhill thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh.
To disengage the song from its encumbrances becomes as time
goes on, a task for the critic-- that specially equipped

official who was
carcely scarcely in
existnce existence when Spenser emerged
with his Faery Queen from the depths of silence.
[He had chosen his medium: & The great English art
was to be, not music, not painting, but the art of words.]

We call Spenser an artist, more so than the
misntels minstrels and

the song writers, because he was aware of his
medoum medium .
H ewas He was conscious of the possibilities and of the

limtations limitations of the English
lang age language . For why, a Gods name,

l.quote: may not we, as else the Greekes, hav the kingdome of our owne
langauge language , and measure our accents by the sound ,

p.l:
reserving the quantity to the verse? He applied
himslef himself
to the art.

And Like the
chornicler chronicler , the writer in order to use
his medium consciously, must be aware of the past. There must
be a golden age behind him; and the present must be fallen,
degenerate. But, while the modern writer with a long line
behind him, naturally at ackes attacks the generation which
which is just gone, --they but are close enough to have
dmagaed damaged what he is seeing partly through their eyes--
the writer in Spensers time had no definite foerebear. antagonist

Spensers rdation revolt is against the
lanaguge language not against not any particular writer, but with

any
particualr particular master of it. He has a sense of the decay

of
langauge language , its
cor eptuino corruption since the purity of Chaucer,

rather than a desire to destroy some actual
predecssor predecessor writer.
He recovered the o old words, Chaucers words. Conscious

perhaps of his own diffusity and sweetness, he tried to recover
stiff stiffen
his words bu the use of Chaucers words, the old words the Old English speech. But together
with this sense of the past, there was present ,what we have ??? in him

the sense of the future. [The sense of the future of the
langauge language
is almost extinct now] But then the writer was aware
of the tumult of the Something was happening;
With his acute sense of words, he must have been aware,

with
agitaion agitation , with distress of what
linece license
ight might befall

this
langauge language ; He must have detected in speech, in

ballds ballads ,
everyhwere everywhere , something loosening, [fraying?], fermenting,
and tried to seize; to harden; to fix the language

l.del:
that was
abo about to be.

quote.l: With that a joyous fellowship issewed
With wanton Bardes and Rhymers impudent

p.l: That was the voice too that was heard too in the great room.

For when we see the great
Elizabthan Elizabethan house--Wilton

say, or
Penshurt Penshurst -- we see the stranded relic that has e
merged emerged like the ribs of a wreck on the shore from the the its surroundings. Could we see it
as it is said that the airman sees a village field with all
the from the air with the old scars of old roads, other villages
and other houses on it. we should see the great house not alone, but

connected with the village.
W We should see a ring, an oasis

and the oasis like a fortress holding out
agianst against the
uncultivated land; stored against the everlasting siege of

nature. If the enemy were man, there was armour
i in the church.
If frost or winter there was grain in the great barn.
That is the connection between great house and small,

between master and
la ouere labourer that is detailed in the Paston

letters, and makes indeed the staple of the
mediaveal medieval
letter writing. But there was also that other connection--
the common belief. That bond between the great house and the
small has faded, till it is like one of those perhaps rather

greener rides
stillto still to be found in England along which,
abntiquaries antiquaries say the Pilgrimsrode to Canterbury. So the
scholars tell us of the roads now faded in the mind.

Long before the
Christains ocame Christians came the tree was a God;
the sun was a God; Earth was God; Death was a God. the

and how this
anceint ancient worship lies beneath the other; how
Mrs Parsons 3/2/74

quote.l: With that a joyous fellowship issued

With wanton bardes and Rhymers
im⅜udent impudent

p.l: --that voice reached Spenser too in the great room.

If the great
Elizabetahn Elizabethan house, (Penshurst, Wilton as we see it
now cluttered with villas and bungalows, looks out

of proportion, it is
beacuse because the connection between the great house
and the small is lost. If we could see it as it was in Spensers
time we should see raying out tracks, raying out from the

great gate to the across the fields to the
cooatge cottage , to
the farms, even to the hovels. there was the It was connected, if war came
by the need of men. There was armour stored in the church. And
[always?]the perpetual fight with nature made tracks from the house to the

farm. A common fight linked the noble to the
labourrer labourer .
That connection, the physical, between master and man

is painfully and
minitelt minutely recorded in the medieval letters.

It is the staple of the whole
correspon nce correspondence --the But there was
also the other the less visible connection--the common belief.

That bond between the
grear great house and the small has been

grown over, like the
t ack track under the hill along whch the

pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one drives
the e there now. But when

Spenser came to Penshurst that
rack track led from one house to another;

pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one drives
the e there now. But when

Spenser came to Penshurst that
rack track led from one house to another;
It led to the village green. It led to the tree: to the well.
In the spring they danced round the Maypole; at midsummer they

lit the bon fire on the hill; at harvest the waggons were
crwoned crowned .

At Christmas the mummers acted their dumb show; the boys
scame came
wassailing. The roads led to the pagan graces, to the stones

where the old pagan
Ebglish English had offered sacrifice.
The peasants still went that way, by instinct; in summer
in spring; in summer in winter. The old Gods still lay behind the
Christian God. The Pagan gods were served and worshipped under cover of

the Christian God at the same time. The sun was a God; the earth a
goodess goddess .

Even if the old gods were
los ng losing their names, the
instinct remained when spring came, or in the cold of winter to do

them
h mage homage , to placate them, to win crops, husbands, health,

detruction destruction of foes. The
dsire desire to enact was coupled with the other

desire--to make something useless; something
unc nnected unconnected with the
daily struggle, to bring out into the day light embodied their own

natiral natural love of play. To be
dresded dressed dredged up, to
emboy embody the beliefs
that were still so strong; when so much depended on the sun; but

also to
emboy embody the
insinct instinct of pleasure; the That sunken road, that
track of ancient belief lay between the master in the great house

and the peasant in the cottage. In the noble as in the
peasnt peasant
murmure murmured
a half articulate anonumous voice murmured of old Gods and evils;

The well and the tree were still haunted. As the s hpalrs [scholars?]
ll tell us

both noble and peasant had the same need to
meboy embody to
preresent present to see

the instinct
personfied personified . Along the roads from town to
twon town from

one great house
toanother to another came the
mistrels minstrels the rhymers the jugglers

the bear leaders, the makers of
ballds ballads and actors of old lege

legends. Even the King and Queen must have their
misnt esl minstrel to
give voice to the hidden instincts. Even though the actor,

partly because his body is his tool partly because the
lsinger singer
and the dancer are outside the pale of daily workers and see the

pagenat pageant irresponsibly often mockingly, the actor was
despsied despised , they
were necessary. Just as one tolerates the person who says what we
are all too proud or too self conscious to say, the minstrel was

despsied despised but
toelerated tolerated . Even the churchmen aware that the homage
was paid not their god but the old discarded god, could not suppress
sinsinct instinct flow into the correct religious channel. If they could they
constrained the jugglers and the bear leaders and the dancers

to put off their leaves, their bells, and striped
clthing clothing

and robe
them sleves themselves in the garb proper to the
miravle miracle play.
This was a great bond between the great house and the

coottage cottage . For
thoug t eh though the great speaking
frech nglish French, English , with

Latin and
reek Greek on their
to gues tongues , might despise the jargon of the
peasant, they shared the memory of what he was doing when he danced,
they knew the old story he acted. Even to the King himself,

it was certain that an evil
sp it spirit dwelt in the woman in the

hovel. When the
pilliw nks pilliwinks were applied to her she confessed

how she
h d had gone to sea in a sieve with two
hu dred hundred other
witched witches

and danced a reel how she had thrown a cat
intot he into the sea and

raised a
stor storm that sunk the
kin s kings ship. Spenser
haerd heard the

r ymers rhymers and the
mummenrs mummers . He was at
he the festival when the

quote.l: And after her came jolly june arrayed
All in greene leaves, as she a player were.

p.l: He had seen the man at the festival, and noted his green leaves

when the Queen had seen the masque at
Kenilsowrth Kenilworth . It was a revival,
already time had given those green leaves their mystery [submitted?] â [before?] in the . Already the

other house was being built:
enslowew Henslowe had jotted down in
h his account

book the
ums sums he had paid for
laths lathes and nails and timber to build a
play house. He had given so much for painting the theatre. He

distance he sees them
pictriallly pictorally ; grouped, like the
figur s figures in a fresco,with the flowers growing at their feet,
behind them marble pillars, trees with bright birds, and

the libbard and the lion
couching couchant or
rampamt rampant . There is no
tension; no direction but always movement, as the metre
flings its curve of sound that, like a wave, breaks always

on the same
pace place . Folded in this
intation incantation we
drwose drowse and
sleep yet always start awake. For the [FQ?] is illuminated.
<Still there is something anonymous about Spenser.
He cannot confine emotions within one person.
He must externalise and symbolise.
But Spenser standing on the threshold of the great room

is half in
shdow shadow , half in light. He is still anonymous
in that he cannot confine emotions within one person.

He must symbolise; exteriorise. If a man is jealous, he
canno cannot
show it save by making a symbol of jealousy. He must
Jealusy Jealousy becomes The feelings of men and women must be

symblised symbolised and given a body outside
th ir their own. He ignores
hims lf himself , the individual. Yet at the same time, forces are at
work that make him conscious of himself, the man who is

separate from the
audeince audience , who is giving the
wolrd world something

of himself,
whois who is conscious of the worlds
scron scorn and neglect
of what he gives. He is aware of his art as Chaucer was

not, nor Langland, nor
Malry Malory . His is no longer a wandering
voice, but the voice of a man practising an art, and
asking for recognition.

Had the poet remained in the great room,
profferig proffering
his book to the little group of readers, English poetry

might
hav have remained a book read aloud; a recollection;
something read by the leisured listening in the great room
to some one reading aloud. But there was the other
voice the voice at the back door, the voice that
Spenser heard himself--- ...of minstrels making goodly

l.quote: With wanton bardes and rhymers impudent.

p.l:
Spenser
ims lf himself had heard it.
H h He had been, it is said,
at the pageant at Kenilworth when to amuse the Queen, an

old story was staged. And
Soenser Spenser noted the player
dressed in green leaves. The nobles it seems,

had a great love of that those
r de rude voices. Ironically
enoug enough

the preacher who was for
banihsing banishing Robin Hood and such

ancient
supersttions superstitions was himself forging the very weapon

that gave the old
misntersl minstrels their le a new lease of life
When Latimer said the Lords Prayer in English at the

beginng beginning and end of his sermon he was
tting putting English into
high places. He was rescuing it from the back door.

He was teaching the nobles how to
r ad read English; he was
making that alliance between the peasant and the noble

which was
necssary necessary , should all classes meet together
at the Globe at the Rose at the Crown.

When the Queen and the poet
togteher together saw the old

paganet pageant with the players still wearing green
levaes leaves at
Kenilworth, the builders of the new theatre were ordering

nails, planks, the the little building was first
theate theatre
was being built, at Southwark, among the stews, When the flag
flew, the poor and the rich came together, in the open air,
and on that stage, without any scenery, but richly dressed,

the old mummers were to act not Robin Hood, not
E ry man Everyman ,

not St Georges play but Faust,
Tamberlaine Tamburlaine , Hamlet, Lear,

and Antony and
Cleoptara Cleopatra .
Parsons 3.2.73
